Load the Excel file `climateMeasurements.xlsx`, reading the first sheet while skipping the first 5 metadata rows so only data rows are retained.
Remove any columns that are completely empty (all‐NaN) to keep only informative variables.
Create a new `year` column calculated as 1950 − (rounded value of `Age_ky.1` × 1000) to convert the age key into calendar years (not directly used for the answer, but part of preprocessing).
Find the smallest value in the column `ODP 967 Dust proxy` and filter the dataframe to the rows that have exactly this minimum dust proxy value.
If multiple rows share this minimum dust proxy, break the tie by selecting the row with the smallest `ODP 967 wet-dry index` among them.
From the resolved single row, extract the value in the `Ca` (calcium) column, which gives the calcium concentration (ppm) at the time of minimum dust proxy.
Output the calcium value and round it to four decimal places for the final answer.
